title: Correct emphasys in the text (substituting quatation mars on itallics)
content:
Hello,  
I am designing the book about a theater.  
The text I am given contains a huge number of quotation marks:

– names of plays  
– role in the play  
– names of artistic groups  
– names of programs  
– citations  
– «ironic» meanings or metaphors,  
– foreign language words

I am trying to make all this emphases less obtrusive by changing all names of theater plays and foreign language words to Italic.  
How legitimate this approach is?

thank you!
author: SergeZuev

comments.content:
I’m pretty sure in most style guides used in the English speaking world it would go like this:

Name of play: italic or underline  
Role in play: initial-cap or (maybe) small-caps  
Name of group: title-cap or italic  
Name of program: title-cap or italic  
Citations: quotation marks  
Irony: quotation marks  
Foreign language: italic

The Compañía Comarcal de Danza demonstrated its _chef d’œuvre_ in 1978 when the _Endless Performance_, an annual show consisting of _The Nutcracker_ and _The Swan Princess_ followed by an immense flamenco show, according to dance historian Juan Doj, “brought the house down, both literally and figuratively.” The Princess was interpreted by Ivana Humpalot, and the Evil Rat King was portrayed by the “graceful” Sancho Panza.
